phrase.item: Wakhan is a country situated between two mountains, to the north and to the south.
Towards the north, Wakhan, towards the south, Afghanistan. A narrow river separates them, we call it the Wakhandaria.
In all of Wakhan, we identify four dialects, of which the different speakers understand eachother.

The first dialect is that of Darchai, Chetkharv, Zmydg, Nobod, Pyp, Vitchekout, Tourgoz, Imtchin. Even so, in the Ptyp area named Tchiltok they speak Persian. They say that the inhabitants of Tchiltok are originally from Zibok in Afghanistan.
Their forefathers, their wives are from Tchitral, we sometimes call them Tchitroti or Ziboki.
They count eight families total in Tchiltok.
From Imtchin to Chirgin it's the same language. (Middle Wakhi)
In Yamg live twenty five families who also speak Persian.
Their vocabulary shows that they also came from Zibok.
There are also Wakhans in Wamg, i.e. Wakhi is spokem by six families; they came from several places.
In Drij there are three of four families where they speal Persian, they call them Khedja.
In Zoung, Zegwynd, [and] Asor: there is only one dialect (Upper Wakhi).
Aside from dialects, all sorts of clans subdivide the population:
some based on the clan that their founder was connected to, some based on the place where they come from, some based on the jobs of thie forefathers, this is why their denominations are varied.
In Kikhn: Baiktor, Betek, Martchinek; in Zeung: Tamochogrou, Sayidon; In Drij: Khedja; In Vrang: Bidjinek, Khaibari, Chana, Kissek, Guedirchoyi.
Before, there were few inhabitants in Wakhan and [there was] much water.
The predominant plantings of grains are wheat, barley, beans, grass peas, peas, millet.
Some places were also sown with alfalfa.
The clan that was the most able had the most land and livestock.
There was large livestock in Wakhan (yaks, donkeys, horses) and small livestock (goats, sheep)
The fieldwork in Wakhan requires much effots: the land is very mountainous and there are many stones.
They collect the stones, dig canals, [and] make fields.
The farmers count four seasons in Wakhan: spring, summer, autumn, winter.
Winter lasts three months: december, january, february.
It snows permanently.
However many warm clothes you have, (fur coats, jackets, fur hats) that is how many you wear.
They prepare [fire]wood.
They grind the grain at the mill, they give hay to the livestock.
The spring is: March, April, May.
This is the season in which they prepare the manure, sow, and labor, dig irrigation furrows, [and] proceed to the first watering [of crops], once the shoots come out, they water.
June, July, August: that's summer.
In june, they transhume all of the livestock to the summering area (summer pasture) so that the animals do not damage the crops.
If there are no women in a home and there is a lot of livestock, the men themselves go to the summer pasture.
The hamlet people go to the pastures to have the livestock graze with the little ones.
The farmers that stay in the hamlet water the fields.
In Wakhan they often water the wheat up to twenty five times because in this region there is a lot of sand, wind, [and] there are dust storms.
In Wakhan there are fruits: apples, apricots, cherries, peaches.
Sometimes, when it's hot out, all of the fruits ripen well and are sweet.
Generally, everything that they plant grows well in Wakhan.
For example there are grapes; among garden crops there are onions, melons, carrots, peppers.
Before, people even sowed the opium poppy and cannabis, [but] no longer.
For a long time ‎‎in Wakhan some people hunted with matchlock rifles.
Around the land, there are mainly wild goats and sheep.
If they happened to come across snow panthers or bears at altitude, they shot them too; they also hunted wolves, foxes, hares, partridge, duck, pigeon.
In the forest they sometmes also hunted lynx, and marmots, wild cats, and grouse in the mountain.
As for faith: all are Ishmaelites on Walhi territory, but there are different Pirs (spiritual elders)

Some considered themselves as distinct clans and have different pirs and different khalifs. But in each locality they worship their "saint": Choqambar Oftob in Liangar, Cho-Isomiddin in Ptyp, Piri Foqmamad in Derchay.
In all of the localities and on all pastures there is a "saint", their names are the following: Poyi-Khodja, Poyi-Dyldyl, Savzi-Kamarband, Tchil-Merid, Selton-Bobodji, Tsebyr-Wyrg and others.
